Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS-1103368
Principal Investigator: Yongbin Ruan

During the past twenty years, there has been a great deal of
interaction between mathematic and physics. Various
correspondences or dualities arising from physics have had a
great impact on mathematics. One of these correspondences is the
Landau-Ginzburg/Calabi-Yau correspondence. This proposal offers a
comprehensive program to establish this correspondence in
mathematics with mathematical rigor. There is a wide range of
applications such as global mirror symmetry, the computation of
Gromov-Witten invariants of compact Calabi-Yau manifolds, and to
modular forms.

Since the era of Newton, mathematics has been a key tool in
helping us to comprehend the universe. An example is
differential geometry via Einstein's theory of general
relativity. During the last twenty years there has been a great
deal of activity in building so-called string-theoretic models of
the universe. The string-theoretic model of the universe is
ten-dimensional, our usual 4-dimensional space-time togeher with
a very small 6-dimensional space called a Calabi-Yau manifold.
Such a small internal space will affect our space-time through
certain mathematical quantities such as Gromov-Witten
invariants. The computation of these invariants has been a
central problem in geometry and physics. This is the area in
which mathematical tools can be very useful. The current
proposal envisages a theoretical framework as well as developing
technical tools to compute Gromov-Witten invariants

POR.DRECONTENT:
A few years ago, PI and his collaborators invented a mathematical theory for so so called Landau-Ginzburg model. It received wide attention and has been named FJRW-theory in the community. One of most important problems for FJRW-theory is its relation to more established theory such as Gromov-Witten theory. This was extensively studied in physics. Twenty years ago, E. Witten invented an 2D quantum field theory called gauged linear sigma model (GLSM) for this purpose. The main goal of this grant was to understand this relationship. After the considerable effort, we have successfully fullfilled our primiary objective by developing a mathematical theory for Witten's gauged linear sigma model. GLSM has a parameter  which interprelates these two different models at different limits. Since the appearane of our paper, a great deal of effort was spent by myself, my students and postdoc to investigate this new model. For example, a paper with my postdoc Dustin Ross carried out the investigation in genus zero for so called quintic 3-fold. Other significant achievement supported by this grant is to find  geometric counterpart of  so called BCFG integrable hierarchies. Twenty years ago, Witten proposed a remarkable conjecture to connect ADE integrable hierarchies to the geometry of moduli space of ADE LG-models. For a long time, it was not clear how to push it beyond ADE cases. We solved the problem by studying the certain symmetry at the geometry as well as integrable hierarchies.
